column4: a quick search of aptitude doesn't reveal that we have madwifi
I can find aircrack-ng, but not a madwifi package
you aren't going to get much help on injection attacks here
I'm not the one who wants the info. If I'm not supposed to be helping with it, I apologise - I'll leave it alone.
its ok... and sorry about the confusion. its just better to keep that questionable stuff off the channel if possible
any old versions could be removed, but its better to remove them with dpkg -r linux-image-VERSION
that's been done, his 19 and 17 series generic-pae are off, but there are still loads of old files left, which there doesn't appear to be linux-image-version files for.
then have him purge them as well. if they are still around he can check with apt-file to see if any package claims the files and if not manually remove them
so do you need a udev rule?
I don't suppose you would be able to help me and Demon|Ubuntu, would you?
i think a udev rule would be the best way. check /lib/udev/rules.d/* for templates and then add a custom rule to /etc/udev/rules.d
maybe... its not something i've ever done.

although it seems to be one line after being generated "SUBSYSTEM=="net", ACTION=="add", DRIVERS=="?*", ATTR{address}=="48:5b:39:8c:06:b8", ATTR{dev_id}=="0x0", ATTR{type}=="1", KERNEL=="eth*", NAME="eth0"
other than ATTR{address} being the MAC i don't really know what the rest means
why would a more specific regex work when the global regex didn't. I would think something else in Demon|Ubuntu's line is wrong.
